articles.headline: Welcome to the Everything Boom, or Maybe the Everything Bubble
articles.snippet: Around the world, nearly every asset class is expensive by historical standards.
articles.abstract: Around the world, nearly every asset class is expensive by historical standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Spain, where there was a debt crisis just two years ago, investors are so eager to buy the government’s bonds that they recently accepted the lowest interest rates since  1789.

articles.headline: G.M. Resists Recalling Trucks Over Brake Lines
articles.snippet: Facing about 1,000 complaints and a yearslong government investigation, G.M. has not recalled 1.8 million trucks with a brake line corrosion problem.
articles.abstract: Facing about 1,000 complaints and a yearslong government investigation, G.M. has not recalled 1.8 million trucks with a brake line corrosion problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from federal regulators and legislators, General Motors this year has been reviewing past safety problems. That has resulted in 54 recalls affecting about 25.7 million vehicles in the United States.

articles.headline: American Apparel Creditor Calls In $10 Million Loan
articles.snippet: Lion Capital, one of the troubled retailer’s longtime lenders, formally demanded payment after the failure of weeks of negotiation caused by the dismissal of the company’s founder.
articles.abstract: Lion Capital, one of the troubled retailer’s longtime lenders, formally demanded payment after the failure of weeks of negotiation caused by the dismissal of the company’s founder.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of intense wrangling, one of American Apparel’s longtime lenders, Lion Capital, has demanded immediate repayment of a $10 million loan it made to the troubled retailer, after negotiations over new terms failed, according to a person with knowledge of the situation.

articles.headline: Investors Are Buying Troubled Golf Courses and Giving Them Makeovers
articles.snippet: While golf is still anathema to many portfolios, investors who have the cash are scooping up distressed clubs and revamping their business models.
articles.abstract: While golf is still anathema to many portfolios, investors who have the cash are scooping up distressed clubs and revamping their business models.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Gaillardia Golf and Country Club opened in 1998, it was to be the crown jewel of golf in Oklahoma City, complete with an 18-hole P.G.A. championship course and a 55,000-square-foot clubhouse of Norman-style architecture. The Gaylord family, best known as Oklahoma media moguls and owners of the Grand Ole Opry, sank a reported $59 million into the project.

articles.headline: In Bulgaria, Corruption and Mistrust Turn Promise Into Pain
articles.snippet: Bank runs and political instability have cast a shadow on the future of the European Union’s poorest member state.
articles.abstract: Bank runs and political instability have cast a shadow on the future of the European Union’s poorest member state.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — The lines of panicked depositors in this threadbare capital evaporated as quickly as they appeared in what may have been the shortest banking crisis in history — or potentially the prelude to something more tumultuous.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Georgi Kantchev

articles.headline: U.S. Scrutiny for Banks Shifts to Commerzbank and Germany
articles.snippet: The authorities are said to have begun settlement talks with Commerzbank over its dealings with Iran, a move that may pave the way toward talks with Deutsche Bank.
articles.abstract: The authorities are said to have begun settlement talks with Commerzbank over its dealings with Iran, a move that may pave the way toward talks with Deutsche Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: A trail of illicit money led the American government on a hunt through the European financial system, generating criminal cases against banks in Britain, Switzerland and most recently, France.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Immigrant Surge Rooted in Law to Curb Child Trafficking
articles.snippet: The White House says it is hindered in the crisis of immigrant minors by a law to fight sex trafficking, which makes it hard to return certain children to their countries.
articles.abstract: The White House says it is hindered in the crisis of immigrant minors by a law to fight sex trafficking, which makes it hard to return certain children to their countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was one of the final pieces of legislation signed into law by President George W. Bush, a measure that passed without controversy, along with a pension bill and another one calling for national parks to be commemorated on quarters.

articles.headline: Wall Street Offers Clinton a Thorny Embrace
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has enjoyed a close relationship with the financial sector, must grapple with a powerful populist surge coursing through national politics, on both the right and the left.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has enjoyed a close relationship with the financial sector, must grapple with a powerful populist surge coursing through national politics, on both the right and the left.
articles.lead_paragraph: As its relationship with Democrats hits a historic low, Wall Street sees a solution on the horizon: Hillary Rodham Clinton.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Ukraine Rebels Are Retreating for Last Stand
articles.snippet: Separatist rebels retreated Monday from positions throughout eastern Ukraine and began building barricades in Donetsk and Luhansk in anticipation of a final stand against advancing government troops.
articles.abstract: Separatist rebels retreated Monday from positions throughout eastern Ukraine and began building barricades in Donetsk and Luhansk in anticipation of a final stand against advancing government troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Separatist rebels retreated Monday from positions in eastern Ukraine, apparently blowing up bridges, and began building barricades in the two largest cities, Donetsk and Luhansk, in anticipation of a final stand against advancing government troops.

articles.headline: Jihadis Tug at Edges of a Staunch American Ally
articles.snippet: Poverty, unemployment and anti-government sentiment in the Jordanian town of Maan have created modest but growing support for Islamic militancy among residents.
articles.abstract: Poverty, unemployment and anti-government sentiment in the Jordanian town of Maan have created modest but growing support for Islamic militancy among residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAAN, Jordan — Hanging from the facade of a shuttered bank on a bustling market street in this sunbaked town were two large, white banners emblazoned with black letters.

articles.headline: Israel and Hamas Trade Attacks as Tension Rises
articles.snippet: Israel carried out extensive air attacks in response to heavy rocket fire and authorized a major call-up of army reserves for an extended campaign against militants in Gaza.
articles.abstract: Israel carried out extensive air attacks in response to heavy rocket fire and authorized a major call-up of army reserves for an extended campaign against militants in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel and Hamas escalated their military confrontation on Tuesday, with Israel carrying out extensive air attacks in response to heavy rocket fire and authorizing a major call-up of army reserves for an extended campaign against militants in Gaza.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Obama Asks for $3.7 Billion to Aid Border
articles.snippet: President Obama’s request for Congress to provide $3.7 billion to confront a surge of migrants crossing the border into Texas quickly became entangled in the fierce debate over immigration.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s request for Congress to provide $3.7 billion to confront a surge of migrants crossing the border into Texas quickly became entangled in the fierce debate over immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama urged Congress on Tuesday to quickly provide almost $4 billion to confront a surge of young migrants from Central America crossing the border into Texas, calling it “an urgent humanitarian situation.”
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Jeremy W. Peters
